verses.text: The LORD reigns, let the nations tremble; he sits enthroned between the cherubim, let the earth shake.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 99 A royal psalm (Ps. 93 note). The psalm may be divided into three uneven stanzas based on a refrain that is repeated three times with some variation (vv. 3, 5, 9).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:1
rsbNotes.text:
99:1 The Lord reigns. See notes Ps. 5:2 and 93:1.

upon the cherubim. Cherubim are spiritual beings who dwell in heaven with God. They are guardians of God’s holiness, as witnessed by their role in protecting the post-Fall garden (Gen. 3:24). Cherubim were symbolically represented in the tabernacle, both in the innermost curtain (Ex. 36:35), and in the Most Holy Place (Ex. 37:1–9). The psalm refers to the cherubim of God’s throne with their outstretched wings above the ark of the covenant.

let the earth quake. At God’s special self-revelations (theophanies) reverberations, like those of a natural earthquake were sometimes felt throughout the earth. See “The Greatness of God” at 1 Chr. 29:11.

verses.text: Great is the LORD in Zion; he is exalted over all the nations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:2
rsbNotes.text: 99:2 in Zion. The location of the temple. See note Ps. 3:4.

verses.text: Let them praise your great and awesome name- he is holy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:3
rsbNotes.text:
99:3 name. See note Ps. 8:1.

Holy is he. This is the refrain of the song (vv. 5, 9); God is set apart from all His creatures. This is evident from His uncreated nature, His power, and His moral perfection.

verses.text: The King is mighty, he loves justice- you have established equity; in Jacob you have done what is just and right.
Exalt the LORD our God and worship at his footstool; he is holy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:4
rsbNotes.text: 99:4 executed justice. See note Ps. 96:10.

verses.text: Moses and Aaron were among his priests, Samuel was among those who called on his name; they called on the LORD and he answered them.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:6
rsbNotes.text:
99:6 Moses . . . Aaron . . . Samuel. Three of the most prominent leaders of Israel in the period before the monarchy. All three served as mediators between God and His people.

called upon his name. The emphasis in this section of the psalm is that God speaks to His people when they turn to Him for help in prayer.

verses.text: He spoke to them from the pillar of cloud; they kept his statutes and the decrees he gave them.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:7
rsbNotes.text: 99:7 the pillar of the cloud. See Ex. 13:21, 22; 40:34–38.

verses.text: O LORD our God, you answered them; you were to Israel a forgiving God, though you punished their misdeeds.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:8
rsbNotes.text: 99:8 an avenger of their wrongdoings. For their own good, and to preserve His holiness, God may punish His people for the sins they commit. Israel knew this because God gave foreign enemies power over them when they persisted in unbelief. This reflects God’s corrective punishment.

verses.text: Exalt the LORD our God and worship at his holy mountain, for the LORD our God is holy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 99:9
rsbNotes.text: 99:9 God is holy. See note on v. 3.
